title: ![](../images/node-red-icon.svg =24x*) Node-RED integration: From the Bottom Up
author: PotOfCoffee2Go
body:
“I am completely operational, all my circuits are functioning perfectly.”

         - HAL 9000 (2001: A Space Odyssey)

This project is but-yet-another-blog-site which contains pages and posts describing techniques using [Node-RED] to handle the [process and data flow] control of HTTP requests to [node.js] applications. A combination of [Node-RED] and [node.js] modules are used to implement the site. Web pages and [RESTful] interface are implemented using [Node-RED] flows. The focus has been to create a software framework to implement HTML and REST access to single-board [Internet of Things (IoT)] hardware. ---- ###### ["Would You Like to Know More?"]
  • Installation
  • Usage
  • What is Node-RED?
  • Single-board systems compatibility
---- This site is made up of only two javascript code files (excluding custom [Node-RED nodes]). `./server.js` is the entry point of the application and `./model/database.js` provides permanent data storage. It is assumed that developers have an intermediate understanding of [HTML], [Node.js], [expressjs], [Markdown], and [Node-RED]. The web based [Ace] editor is used to create and edit the site page/post entries, while [Showdown] is used to convert [Markdown] text to [HTML]. The web pages use [BootStrap] V4 in an attempt to be [mobile friendly]. Minimal knowledge of [Ace], [BootStrap], and [Showdown] is sufficient. - Embed [Node-RED] into an [expressjs] server application. - Creation and debugging of application specific [Node-RED nodes]. - Operation on single board systems (low cpu/memory footprint) - [Raspberry Pi], [BeagleBoard], [Intel Edison], etc. ---- ###### ["Would You Like to Know More?"]
  • Embed Node-RED into Expressjs server
  • Application specific Node-RED nodes
  • Single-board systems compatibility
---- The [MVC] paradigm is used as a framework. A JSON file stores data, keeping inline with the minimalist concept of [Node-RED]. [Node-RED] accesses the `model and business logic` (database) via four javascript procedures `newPost`, `getPosts`, `updatePost`, and `deletePost` which are analogous to the [CRUD] operations in a [RESTful] interface. [Business] logic is implemented with-in the `model` component as suggested by the [MVC] paradigm. For larger machines, one could implement the four javascript procedures to access _for example_ [MySQL], [Oracle], or [MongoDB]; which would work without any changes to the [Node-RED] flows as long as the resulting data content, format, and order are identical. - Interface [Node-RED] to [MVC] model and business logic components written as conventional [node.js] modules. ---- ###### ["Would You Like to Know More?"]
  • MVC model and business logic
  • Common Node.js Database Modules
---- The MVC [controller and view] components are implemented using [Node-RED] flows. The `controller` part is straight forward by using [Node-RED] `Http in and out` nodes. Web page `views` are constructed using the [Node-RED] built-in [mustache template engine] `template node`. Mustache is logic-less, which basically means there is only a most basic method to implement if-then-else conditionals with-in the template. Because of this, [Presentation] Logic is implemented as a Node-RED [sub-flow] to be shared by higher level flows. - Implement [MVC] control, view, and [presentation] logic components using [node-red] flows. - Using [node-red] sub-flows for presentation of web page styles, header, footer, navigation, and client-side scripts . ---- ###### ["Would You Like to Know More?"]
  • Node-RED subflows
  • MVC control, view, and presentation logic
  • Building presentation logic in Node-RED
---- ###### ["Would You Like to Know More?"]
  • Site Web Page Flows
  • Site RESTful flows
---- > **Note:** This project is an instructive tool installing itself locally at `http://localhost:8081`. **Anybody** with access to the site can modify blog pages and posts. ---- **Discuss**: - Situations when a conventional nodejs module is appropriate versus a node-red node - Scenarios when usage of node-red sub-flows is advantageous **IMHO**: - Where is the **'Logic'** in [MVC]??? ---- ### Installation To see if you are interested, or wish to only see blog pages and posts: ```bat npm install node-red-from-the-bottom cd node-red-from-the-bottom npm start ``` Then in address bar of your web browser: ``` http://localhost:8081 ``` However; `node-red-from-the-bottom` is designed to be cloned so that you can inspect, modify, and play around with it. ```bat git clone https://github.com/PotOfCoffee2Go/node-red-from-the-bottom.git cd node-red-from-the-bottom npm install npm start ``` ---- ["Would You Like to Know More?"]: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kdrjzE1SE58 title: What is node-RED?
author: PotOfCoffee2Go
body:
[Node-RED] is a [flow based] programming language developed and maintained on [GitHub] by UK based [IBM Emerging Technology Group], licensed with the family of open-source projects sponsored by the [JS Foundation]. [Node-RED] has been designed primarily to implement data flows for [Internet of Things (IoT)] technologies. It has a small cpu/memory footprint allowing operation on single board devices such as [Raspberry Pi], [BeagleBoard], [Intel Edison], etc. One of the objectives is to use only the [core nodes] provided by the standard [Node-RED] install along with implementation of site specific [nodes]. - Embed [Node-RED] into an express site - Programmatically set [Node-RED] configuration parameters - Use [Node-RED] to implement process flows initiated by HTTP requests - Deliver HTML and/or RESTful content using [Node-RED] flows - Delivery of static content (css, js, images, etc.) along side [Node-RED] flows - How to interface [Node-RED] `function` nodes to nodejs `modules` - Creation and debugging of application specific [Node-RED nodes] - Sharing of [Node-RED] code via sub-flows ---- ###### ["Would You Like to Know More?"]
  • Blog Site Usage
  • What is Node-RED?
  • Web Page Flows
  • RESTful flows
---- ---- ###### ["Would You Like to Know More?"]
  • Site Usage
  • HTML page Flows
  • REST request Flows
---- Process [flows] are implemented via a graphical browser-based flow editor (`Node-RED Editor`) used to describe sequences of [data flow] movement (`msg`) between one or more _independent_ synchronous and/or asynchronous processes (`nodes`). Flows modified in the `Node-RED Editor` are immediately implemented by _deploying_ flow changes to the [Node-RED] runtime. The transmission of data consists of `wires` between one or more in/out `ports` assigned to each `node`. The wires determine the path of the `msg` data object which is the primary interaction between `nodes`. Node-RED also provides global contexts allowing nodes to share common data and functions. A `flow` is a sequence of `nodes` that are wired together. Since multiple `wires` can be connected to a single in/out `port`, a `flow` can have multiple paths which node-red executes concurrently. The data `msg` content is cloned for each path thus the content of `msg` from one `path` can diverge from the `msg` content of another path. [Node-RED] can run as a standalone application or can be embedded as a module of a node.js application. ["Would You Like to Know More?"]: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kdrjzE1SE58 [Node-RED]: https://nodered.org/ [flow based]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flow-based_programming [flows]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flow-based_programming [GitHub]: https://github.com/node-red [IBM Emerging Technology Group]: https://emerging-technology.co.uk/ [JS Foundation]: https://js.foundation/community/projects [data flow]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dataflow_programming [Node-RED nodes]: https://nodered.org/docs/creating-nodes/ [Internet of Things (IoT)]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_of_things [Raspberry Pi]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raspberry_Pi [BeagleBoard]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BeagleBoard [Intel Edison]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intel_Edison [core nodes]: https://github.com/node-red/node-red/tree/master/nodes/core [nodes]: https://nodered.org/docs/creating-nodes/
